title: Purity and Jealousy Laws
shortSummary: Numbers Chapter 5 outlines God's instructions to Moses concerning the removal of impurity from the camp of Israel and the procedures for restitution of sin. It also details the law of jealousy, a ritual for a husband to bring before the priest when he suspects his wife of adultery, emphasizing God's concern for holiness and justice within the community.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Journey after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet of Israel who receives and conveys God's commands to the people.

keyCharacters.name: The Priest
keyCharacters.description: The religious official who administers the laws, including the ritual of jealousy and atonement offerings.

keyCharacters.name: The Jealous Husband
keyCharacters.description: A man who suspects his wife of unfaithfulness and brings her to the priest for the ritual of jealousy.

keyCharacters.name: The Wife
keyCharacters.description: The woman suspected of adultery who undergoes the ritual to determine her guilt or innocence.

definitions.definition: A person afflicted with leprosy, a skin disease considered ritually unclean, requiring exclusion from the camp.
A bodily discharge, often referring to a condition that causes ritual impurity.
A barley meal offering without oil or frankincense, used in the ritual to test a wife's faithfulness.
Water mixed with dust from the tabernacle floor and a curse, used in the ritual to bring a curse upon a guilty wife.

outline.heading: Exclusion of the Impure from the Camp
outline.description: God commands the Israelites to remove all lepers, those with bodily discharges, and anyone defiled by contact with the dead from the camp to maintain holiness where God dwells.

outline.heading: Restitution for Sins Against Others
outline.description: Instructions are given for confessing sins and making restitution with an added fifth part, emphasizing accountability and reconciliation within the community.

outline.heading: The Law of Jealousy Introduced
outline.description: The procedure begins for a husband who suspects his wife of adultery, including the presentation of a special offering by the wife to the priest.

outline.heading: The Ritual of the Bitter Water
outline.description: The detailed ritual involves the priest preparing bitter water with dust from the tabernacle floor, administering an oath to the wife, and the consequences of guilt or innocence, highlighting God's justice and the seriousness of marital fidelity.

application: Maintain personal and communal holiness by avoiding sin and impurity, recognizing God’s presence among His people.
Confess and make restitution for wrongs committed against others to restore relationships and honor God’s justice.
Trust in God's justice and mercy when facing accusations or doubts, seeking His guidance through prayer and godly counsel.
Respect the sanctity of marriage and uphold faithfulness as a reflection of our covenant relationship with God.

keyVerses.text: Both male and female shall ye put out, without the camp shall ye put them; that they defile not their camps, in the midst whereof I dwell.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores God's holiness and the need for purity among His people, emphasizing separation from sin.

keyVerses.text: Then they shall confess their sin which they have done: and he shall recompense his trespass with the principal thereof, and add unto it the fifth part thereof, and give it unto him against whom he hath trespassed.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the importance of confession and making full restitution for sins against others.

keyVerses.text: And when he hath made her to drink the water, then it shall come to pass, that, if she be defiled, and have done trespass against her husband, that the water that causeth the curse shall enter into her, and become bitter, and her belly shall swell, and her thigh shall rot: and the woman shall be a curse among her people.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the serious consequences of adultery and the divine judgment involved in the ritual.

keyVerses.text: Then shall the man be guiltless from iniquity, and this woman shall bear her iniquity.
keyVerses.significance: It clarifies the outcome of the ritual, protecting the innocent husband and holding the guilty accountable.
